pullRequest.title: Add object builders to simplify the process of creating Villager professions
pullRequest.bodyText:
As a requirement for creating villager professions, we also expose allowing the creation of PointOfInterestTypes for workstations.
The PR also comes with some generic TradeOffers.Factorys for generation of some trades since mojang made these implementations static inner classes, though anyone could make their own trades just by implementing the api.
I thought these additions would work best in the object builders module since this involves the creation of villager professions, point of interest types and trade offer factories.

nodes.bodyText: maybe just name it workstation?
harvestableItem?

Note this does not register any trades to these villagers. To register trades, add a new entry with your profession as the key to {@link TradeOffers#PROFESSION_TO_LEVELED_TRADE}. + */ +public interface VillagerProfessionBuilder { + /** + * Creates a builder to make a {@link VillagerProfession}. + * @return A new builder. + */ + static VillagerProfessionBuilder builder() { + return new VillagerProfessionBuilderImpl(); + } + + VillagerProfessionBuilder id(Identifier id); + + /** + * The {@link PointOfInterestType} the villager will search for when finding it's workstation. + * @param type The {@link PointOfInterestType}. + * @return this builder. + */ + VillagerProfessionBuilder workstationPointOfInterest(PointOfInterestType type); + + /** + * An item that a Villager may harvest in this profession. + * + *

In Vanilla this is used by the farmer to define what type of crops the farmer can harvest. + * + * @param item An item. + * @return this builder. + */ + VillagerProfessionBuilder gatherableItem(Item item);

nodes.bodyText: Call Registry.register here instead maybe? Not sure which is better to do.
BuyItem?
Should Identifier be passed in here? and possibly PointOfInterestType? Im not too sure, it shouldnt matter too much as you do check when building.
Im not a fan of having this logic here
I prefer this be a final utility class (private constructor)

At minimum, a {@link VillagerProfession} requires an {@link VillagerProfessionBuilder#id(Identifier) Identifier}

nodes.bodyText: For these methods obtaining builder instances: I am strongly against requiring params for builder creation. This reduces the reusability of builders imo and hampers centralized builder control (e.g. if you have a global builder repository that offers new builder instnaces by type on demand)
final class with private constructor suggested over interfaces
I don't find a need for this method. Why add this?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright (c) 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019 FabricMC
+ *
+ * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
+ * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
+ * You may obtain a copy of the License at

+ *
+ * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
+ * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
+ * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
+ * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
+ * limitations under the License.
+ */
+
+package net.fabricmc.fabric.api.world.poi.v1;
+
+import java.util.Set;
+import java.util.function.Predicate;
+
+import com.google.common.collect.ImmutableSet;
+
+import net.minecraft.block.Block;
+import net.minecraft.block.BlockState;
+import net.minecraft.util.Identifier;
+import net.minecraft.util.registry.Registry;
+import net.minecraft.world.poi.PointOfInterestType;
+
+import net.fabricmc.fabric.mixin.object.builder.PointOfInterestTypeAccessor;
+
+/**
+ * This class provides utilities to create a {@link PointOfInterestType}.
+ */
+public interface PointOfInterestHelper {
+	/**
+	 * Registers and creates a {@link PointOfInterestType}.
+	 * @param workStationStates A list of {@link BlockState BlockStates} which this {@link PointOfInterestType} can be present on.
+	 * @param id The id of this {@link PointOfInterestType}.
+	 * @param ticketCount The amount of tickets.
+	 * @param searchDistance The search distance.
+	 * @return a new {@link PointOfInterestType}.
+	 */
+	static PointOfInterestType create(Set<BlockState> workStationStates, Identifier id, int ticketCount, int searchDistance) {
+		return Registry.POINT_OF_INTEREST_TYPE.add(id, PointOfInterestTypeAccessor.callSetup(PointOfInterestTypeAccessor.callCreate(id.toString(), workStationStates, ticketCount, searchDistance)));
+	}
+
+	/**
+	 * Registers and creates a {@link PointOfInterestType}.
+	 * @param workStationStates A list of {@link BlockState BlockStates} which this {@link PointOfInterestType} can be present on.
+	 * @param id The id of this {@link PointOfInterestType}.
+	 * @param ticketCount The amount of tickets.
+	 * @param completionCondition A {@link Predicate} which determines whether this point of interest type should be present.
+	 * @param searchDistance The search distance.
+	 * @return a new {@link PointOfInterestType}.
+	 */
+	static PointOfInterestType register(Set<BlockState> workStationStates, Identifier id, int ticketCount, Predicate<PointOfInterestType> completionCondition, int searchDistance) {
+		return Registry.POINT_OF_INTEREST_TYPE.add(id, PointOfInterestTypeAccessor.callSetup(PointOfInterestTypeAccessor.callCreate(id.toString(), workStationStates, ticketCount, completionCondition, searchDistance)));
+	}
+
+	/**
+	 * Gets all possible {@link BlockState BlockStates} a Block could have.
+	 * @param block The block to get all states from.
+	 * @return All possible {@link BlockState BlockStates} the block could contain.
+	 */
+	static Set<BlockState> getAllStatesOf(Block block) {

nodes.bodyText: I suggest merging 3 subinterfaces into 1 interface and convert this into an interface (like how ClientSideNetworkRegistry has an INSTANCE field that is populated by a ClientSideNetworkRegistryImpl) than having 3 impl instances in 3 public static final fields in the 3 subinterfaces. Also makes it easier for users.
Should throw IllegalStateException than NullPointerException imo
This is like the rate of price growth after usage of this offer
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,123 @@ +/* + * Copyright (c) 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019 FabricMC + * + * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); + * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. + * You may obtain a copy of the License at + * + * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 + * + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software + * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and + * limitations under the License. + */ + +package net.fabricmc.fabric.api.trading.v1; + +import net.minecraft.entity.passive.VillagerEntity; +import net.minecraft.item.Item; +import net.minecraft.item.ItemConvertible; +import net.minecraft.item.ItemStack; +import net.minecraft.village.TradeOffer; +import net.minecraft.village.TradeOffers; + +import net.fabricmc.fabric.impl.object.builder.TradeOfferFactoryImpl; + +/** + * Represents some generic {@link TradeOffers.Factory} implementations since the vanilla factories are package private classes. + * + *

The {@link TradeOffers.Factory}s generated are used in generating {@link TradeOffer}s for Villagers and Wandering Traders. + */ +public interface TradeOfferFactory { + TradeOfferFactory INSTANCE = new TradeOfferFactoryImpl(); + + /** + * Represents a trade where a villager buys an item and for one emerald, will "process" the item. + * + *

This is commonly used for cooking items (6 emeralds + 8 raw pork -> 8 cooked pork). + * @param itemConvertible The item to be processed + * @param secondCount The required amount of the item being processed. + * @param sellItem The item which is sold back to the player. + * @param sellCount The amount of the item sold back to the player. + * @param maxUses The amount of "uses" a trade can take before a villager needs to restock. + * @param experience The amount of experience the {@link VillagerEntity Villager} will receive. + * @return A new trade offer factory. + */ + default TradeOffers.Factory createProcessItemFactory(ItemConvertible itemConvertible, int secondCount, Item sellItem, int sellCount, int maxUses, int experience) { + return this.createProcessItemFactory(itemConvertible, secondCount, 1, sellItem, sellCount, maxUses, experience); + } + + /** + * Represents a trade where a villager buys an item and for a few emeralds, will "process" the item. + * + *

This is commonly used for cooking items (6 emeralds + 8 raw pork -> 8 cooked pork). + * @param itemConvertible The item to be processed + * @param secondCount The required amount of the item being processed. + * @param price The required amount of emeralds. + * @param sellItem The item which is sold back to the player. + * @param sellCount The amount of the item sold back to the player. + * @param maxUses The amount of "uses" a trade can take before a villager needs to restock. + * @param experience The amount of experience the {@link VillagerEntity Villager} will receive. + * @return A new trade offer factory. + */ + TradeOffers.Factory createProcessItemFactory(ItemConvertible itemConvertible, int secondCount, int price, Item sellItem, int sellCount, int maxUses, int experience); + + /** + * Represents a trade offer where a villager will sell an item or amount of items for some emeralds. + * @param item The item this villager will sell. + * @param price The amount of emeralds needed to buy this item. + * @param count The amount of the item sold. + * @param maxUses The amount of "uses" a trade can take before a villager needs to restock. + * @param experience The amount of experience the {@link VillagerEntity Villager} will receive. + * @return A new trade offer factory. + */ + default TradeOffers.Factory createSellItemFactory(Item item, int price, int count, int maxUses, int experience) { + return this.createSellItemFactory(new ItemStack(item), price, count, maxUses, experience); + } + + /** + * Represents a trade offer where a villager will sell an item or amount of items for some emeralds. + * @param itemStack The item this villager will sell. + * @param price The amount of emeralds needed to buy this item. + * @param count The amount of the item sold. + * @param maxUses The amount of "uses" a trade can take before a villager needs to restock. + * @param experience The amount of experience the {@link VillagerEntity Villager} will receive. + * @return A new trade offer factory. + */ + default TradeOffers.Factory createSellItemFactory(ItemStack itemStack, int price, int count, int maxUses, int experience) { + return this.createSellItemFactory(itemStack, price, count, maxUses, experience, 0.05F); + } + + /** + * Represents a trade offer where a villager will sell an item or amount of items for some emeralds. + * @param itemStack The item this villager will sell. + * @param price The amount of emeralds needed to buy this item. + * @param count The amount of the item sold. + * @param maxUses The amount of "uses" a trade can take before a villager needs to restock. + * @param experience The amount of experience the {@link VillagerEntity Villager} will receive. + * @param multiplier A price multiplier which represents a possible deviation from the standard price.

nodes.bodyText:
Due to the fact that we know the first slot is always emeralds, I propose the following name changes:

itemConvertible -> buyItem, in contrast to sellItem
secondCount -> buyCount, in contrast to sellCount
price -> emeraldPrice, as it's always for emeralds

This branches up to the top levels as well, so I'll leave small markers when appropriate.

Name change suggestions:

itemStack -> buyStack
price -> emeraldPrice, as noted in the above comment
count -> buyCount to match other methods

Name change suggestions:

itemConvertible -> buyItem
price -> buyAmount

I would put a newline before the params for readability (and it seems to be what most other API docs do). It might also make sense to double space the area between the parameter names and the descriptions. Only placing a comment here because it's at the top of the review page, but it applies to other methods as well. As for the method description, what if we opted to use a list; maybe something like this? Represents a trade where a Villager processes an item at the cost of 1 Emerald.

Examples:

  • 3x Raw Porkchop + 1x Emerald -> 3x Cooked Porkchop
  • 4x Iron Ore + 1x Emerald -> 4x Iron Ingot
Excuse my potentially incorrect HTML.

The {@link TradeOffers.Factory}s generated are used in generating {@link TradeOffer}s for Villagers and Wandering Traders. + */ +public interface TradeOfferFactory { + TradeOfferFactory INSTANCE = new TradeOfferFactoryImpl(); + + /** + * Represents a trade where a villager buys an item and for one emerald, will "process" the item. + * + *

This is commonly used for cooking items (6 emeralds + 8 raw pork -> 8 cooked pork). + * @param itemConvertible The item to be processed + * @param secondCount The required amount of the item being processed. + * @param sellItem The item which is sold back to the player. + * @param sellCount The amount of the item sold back to the player. + * @param maxUses The amount of "uses" a trade can take before a villager needs to restock. + * @param experience The amount of experience the {@link VillagerEntity Villager} will receive. + * @return A new trade offer factory. + */

nodes.bodyText:
Allows the creation of... -> Allows for the creation of...
Alternatively, something like This class provides a builder for creating new {@link VillagerProfession} instances. may work.

What about "Provides a new instance of the default VillagerProfessionBuilder implementation class.", or something along those lines?
The description is a good start-- I would just add a little bit more information to it.

it's -> its, would also capitalize villager.
I'm thinking it could be tweaked to...
Sets the {@link PointOfInterestType} a Villager with this profession will attempt to search for when finding its workstation.
The param should also be tweaked to be similar to the method descriptor, or removed. My recommendation is:
@param workstation  workstation POI the Villager will search for
(with type -> workstation parameter change)

Small issue, but
In Vanilla this -> In Vanilla, this
There's also inconsistent vanilla capitalization in this class-- I think lowercase is more appropriate.
As mentioned above, this param tag doesn't give any useful information. Maybe...
@param items  items harvestable by this profession.

Start of the description needs a small tweak-- maybe something like Collection of blocks that suffice as a job site for this profession? Not sure what the best way to refer to varargs is here...
param -> @param blocks  collection of job site blocks

This specific overload of the method only takes one emerald to process the item

+ * + *

Examples + *

    + *
  • 3x Emeralds -> 2x White Banners + *
  • 1x Emeralds -> 6x Cooked Chicken + *
+ * + * @param sellItem The item this villager will sell. + * @param emeraldPrice The amount of emeralds needed to buy this item. + * @param sellCount The amount of the item sold. + * @param maxUses The amount of "uses" a trade can take before a villager needs to restock. + * @param experience The amount of experience the {@link VillagerEntity Villager} will receive. + * @return A new trade offer factory. + */ + default TradeOffers.Factory createSellItemFactory(Item sellItem, int emeraldPrice, int sellCount, int maxUses, int experience) { + return this.createSellItemFactory(new ItemStack(sellItem), emeraldPrice, sellCount, maxUses, experience); + } + + /** + * Represents a trade offer where a villager will sell an item or amount of items for some emeralds. + * + *

Examples + *

    + *
  • 1x Oak Boat -> 1x Emerald + *
+ * + * @param buyItem The type of item the villager is buying. + * @param buyAmount The amount of items needed to receive one emerald. + * @param maxUses The amount of "uses" a trade can take before a villager needs to restock. + * @param experience The amount of experience the {@link VillagerEntity Villager} will receive. + * @return A new trade offer factory. + */ + TradeOffers.Factory createBuyItemForOneEmeraldFactory(ItemConvertible buyItem, int buyAmount, int maxUses, int experience); + + /** + * Turns a {@link TradeOffer} into a {@link TradeOffers.Factory}. + * + *

Since TradeOffers which currently belong to a villager are mutable, we serialize and then create a new offer to be wrapped. + * + * @param offer The offer to wrap. + * @return A new trade offer factory. + */ + static TradeOffers.Factory wrap(TradeOffer offer) { + return (entity, random) -> new TradeOffer(offer.toTag());

beforeCommit.message: Freeze the wrap offer method a bit better and fix a weird typo in docs.

afterCommit.message: Freeze the wrap offer method a bit better and fix a weird typo in docs.

commit.message: Add Object builders for simplifying the process of creating villager professions and point of interest types.

afterCommit.message: Add Object builders for simplifying the process of creating villager professions and point of interest types.

nodes.bodyText:
This class is rather odd, why does it mix create and register method names for no obvious reason?
A standalone create sounds like it'd create an instance of the containing class, register is similarly a bit too context-less for my taste.
The implementation looks a lot like it deserves a common (private?) method that does the actual registration with the other methods only restructuring the inputs.
I am not convinced it is a good idea to use an interface for the builder, the impl looks simple enough to embed here.
"can be present on" sounds too vague for me

The description could help disambiguate the various overloads by telling what is special about each.
Blank line after the 1st sentence and/or before the tag area please.
